discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
D is correct, the router ID is not necesarilly the same as the IP we use to reach the neighbor

choices.B: The router ID of the neighbor is 100.64.2.254.
choices.A: The BGP neighbor is advertising the 10.20.30.40/24 network to the local router.
choices.C: The BGP state of the two BGP participants is OpenConfirm.
choices.D: The local router is advertising the 10.20.30.40/24 network to its BGP neighbor.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
Correct answer is B.
The cookie mechanism that defends against DoS attacks is implemented during the IKE_SA_INIT exchange. This phase is responsible for establishing the initial parameters and performing a Diffie-Hellman exchange, while also using a cookie challenge to verify the initiator's address before allocating significant resources.

questions.question_text: Which exchange takes care of DoS protection in IKEv2?

choices.B: The remote gateway has quick mode selectors containing a destination subnet of 10.1.2.0/24.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: BD
Correct answer is BD!

From the snippet we can see that DPD is turned on (dpd: mode=on-demand on=1…) and that the IPsec SA is using a 2048‐entry replay window (replaywin=2048), which implies anti‐replay is enabled. So, C is incorrect (DPD is enabled, not disabled) and D is correct (anti‐replay is enabled).

For the quick‐mode selectors, FortiGate labels the local subnet as src and the remote subnet as dst from its own perspective. Here, src=0:10.1.2.0/255.255.255.0 and dst=0:10.1.1.0/255.255.255.0 indicates the other side (the remote FortiGate) sees its “destination” as `10.1.2.0/24.” That makes B correct. Conversely, the tunnel ID and arrow notation show that 10.200.4.1 is the remote gateway IP, so A is not correct.

Selected Answer: AD
The correct statements are:
A. The remote gateway IP is 10.200.5.1.
You can see this in the "serial-1 10.200.5.1:0->10.200.4.1:0" portion of the output.
D. Anti-replay is enabled.
The output shows "replaywin-2048", which indicates that anti-replay is enabled with a replay window of 2048 packets.

choices.C: FortiGate redirected the client to the captive portal to authenticate, so that a correct policy match could be made.
choices.D: FortiGate applied only IPS inspection to this session.
choices.B: FortiGate is performing a security profile inspection using the CPU.
choices.A: FortiGate forwarded this session without any inspection.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
"For TCP, the first number (from left to right) is related to the server-side state and is 0 when the session is not subject to any inspection (flow or proxy). If flow or proxy inspection is done, then the first digit will be different from 0."
From there we can deduce that this session is subject to some kind of inspection and we can also know that the CPU is processesing it because of the NPU state (traffic is not being accelerated)

choices.C: The npu_flag for this tunnel is 02.
choices.B: The npu_flag for this tunnel is 03.
choices.D: Different SPI values are a result of auto-negotiation being disabled for phase 2 selectors.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: AB
Anti-replay is enabled
since encryption and decryption is offloaded npu_flag=3

Selected Answer: AB
AB - For npu_flag refer to https://community.fortinet.com/t5/FortiGate/Technical-Tip-Ensuring-IPSec-traffic-is-offloaded-for-improved/ta-p/193493

Selected Answer: AB
npu for encryption and decryption
